snippet: Ryan Freel, who committed suicide last year, has become the first baseball player linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a disease more commonly associated with football players.
abstract: Ryan Freel, who committed suicide in 2012, has become the first baseball player linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy, disease more commonly associated with football players; examination of his brain tissue by medical researchers at Boston University concluded that severe symptoms plaguing Freel, who played baseball with abandon, could be traced to collisions involving his head.
lead_paragraph: Ryan Freel, who committed suicide last year, has become the first baseball player linked to chronic traumatic encephalopathy, a disease more commonly associated with football players.

headline.main: Playing With Abandon May Have Exacted Toll
headline.print_headline: Across the Fields, Tales of Trauma
